courseDescription: Introduction, practical training, and development of basic piano skills, including the playing of scales, arpeggios, chords, and simple songs; sight reading, transposition, harmonization of melodies, and improvisation.  (For music majors only)

Introduction, practical training, and development of basic piano skills, including the playing of scales, arpeggios, chords, and simple songs; sight reading, transposition, harmonization of melodies, and improvisation.  (For music majors only)
Continued practical training and development of basic piano skills.  (For music majors only)
Introduction, practical training, and development of basic singing skills.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Discipline and consistency in vocal practice

courseDescription: This course covers fundamentals of live audio engineering, rudimentary acoustics, auditory perception and psychoacoustical concepts. Students will learn to assemble sound reinforcement systems for small and large ensembles and examine how sound is perceived by the human ear. Topics such as signal flow, cabling, mixing, busing and monitoring will be addressed. Sound Recording Technology majors must earn a grade of C or better to progress to MUSC 115.
Technical and Digital Skills: Perception of sound by the human ear
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of sound systems for small and large ensembles

courseDescription: This course is designed specifically for non-music majors and focuses on the fundamentals of music theory. It introduces the basics of music – such as rhythm, melody, and harmony – and may progress into intermediate topics such as chord progressions and aural skill development.

This course provides the knowledge of and skills in music theory fundamentals necessary to prepare for upper levels of music theory. Non-music majors may take the course if there is room and with the permission of the instructor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to apply music theory fundamentals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate with peers and instructor

courseTitle: Honors: Music in History and Culture
courseDescription: A survey of major composers and their works in the historical context of different style periods, including a discussion of the central philosophical and cultural issues of each period.  Students will be required to attend at least three musical events and turn in written critiques.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying historical and stylistic elements in music
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the cultural and philosophical context of music
Evaluating the works of major composers

courseDescription: Practical training and development of piano skills needed in the elementary, secondary choral, and private vocal studio setting. Focus will be placed on preparing for the piano barrier exam for music education majors (including technical skills, rehearsal skills, and sight reading). (For Music Education vocal/guitar/keyboard majors only.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instruction communication in a private vocal studio setting
Interpersonal skills in a choral setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting rehearsal techniques to different settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a choral or private vocal studio

courseDescription: This course is designed to help students make the most out of their experience as a student at ODU, create a sense of community among music students, and prepare students for the expectations of being a college student in the Diehn School of Music. Musicians' health topics, among others, will be presented to enhance student rehearsal and performance practices.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and adhering to college expectations
Applying health knowledge to enhance performance

courseDescription: This course is designed to cultivate a nuanced comprehension of the intellectual dimensions of music, equipping students with the analytical skills essential for critical engagement with diverse musical genres and concepts. Through the development of critical thought and the utilization of scholarly tools, students will explore intriguing questions, laying a foundation upon which they will construct additional musical knowledge and expertise during their tenure at the Diehn School of Music.
Technical and Digital Skills: Critical analysis of diverse musical genres
Utilization of scholarly tools for research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and presentation of musical ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical engagement with diverse musical genres and concepts
Formulation of intriguing questions regarding music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Development of a foundation for further musical knowledge and expertise
Planning and execution of in-depth musical research

courseDescription: Music Theory 1 is a foundational course and topics within this course include the basics of music notation, clefs, simple and compound meters, major and minor scales and keys signatures, modes, intervals, triads, seventh chords, inversions, Roman numerals, and an introduction to species counterpoint. This course includes discussions of the pedagogy of music fundamentals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of simple and compound meters
Knowledge of major and minor scales and keys signatures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in music composition and arrangement

courseDescription: Topics for this course include functionalizing two-part counterpoint, introduction to SATB part-writing, function theory, cadences, and connecting the tonic and dominant areas. Other topics include chordal harmonies, realizing figured bass, the submediant and mediant harmonies, motives and motivic analysis, twelve-bar blues, popular song forms/chord symbols/chord extensions/harmonic schemas, and an introduction to jazz theory.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding popular song forms, chord symbols, chord extensions, harmonic schemas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Connecting the tonic and dominant areas
Understanding the submediant and mediant harmonies

courseDescription: Aural Skills 2 continues to develop melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic dictation as well as sight-singing/solfege, aural recognition, and writing of various intervals and triads.
Technical and Digital Skills: Writing of various intervals and triads

courseDescription: This course is designed to be an introduction to the appreciation and understanding of music through music listening activities and a survey of music history.  Basic principles and elements of music are discussed in relation to contexts within a variety of musical styles including classical, jazz, popular, and world music.  Regular and repeated listening is an important part of the course in addition to required concert attendance.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding basic principles and elements of music
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and interpretation of music in historical and cultural context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of different musical styles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for regular and repeated listening

courseDescription: Required for music majors. Available to qualified non-majors. Exploration of music and cultures of the world in terms of function, style, genre, instruments, performers, and individual works. This course offers an exploration of the global mosaic of musical expressions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding various music styles and functions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and presentation of musical expressions

courseDescription: Special topics.

This course will introduce the historical, philosophical, and sociological foundations and contemporary issues of American public education. Also included is an introduction to music education methods and learning theories as they relate to PreK-12 music education, the study of the Virginia Standards of Learning, the National Core Arts Standards for Music and an investigation into teaching for musical understanding, designing musical problems, lesson planning and assessment.  In addition, the course will include reading and writing assignments and discussion with teachers and young musicians. All students will complete a 30-hour observation experience in an appropriate PreK-12 setting specific to music education. In order to receive the required school observation placement, students must complete the ODU Teacher Education background check/clearance process prior to the beginning of this course and register for the observation placement on the Teacher Education web pages. See the advisor for more information. Students are expected independently to register for and take the Praxis Core examination or equivalent while enrolled in this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Virginia Standards of Learning
Familiarity with National Core Arts Standards for Music
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate with teachers and young musicians
Reading and writing assignments related to music education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and completing a 30-hour observation experience in a PreK-12 setting
Initiative to complete background check/clearance process
Independently registering for and taking the Praxis Core examination

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students.  Designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching the trumpet and F horn.  (offered fall semesters)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching trumpet and F horn skills
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adjusting teaching methods based on student's learning style

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. Designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching  trombone, euphonium, and tuba.  (offered spring semesters)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to individual student needs

courseTitle: Music Education: Clarinet and Oboe Class
courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. Designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching the clarinet and oboe, which serves as a foundation for the other woodwind instruments (offered fall semesters).
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and teaching the foundations of woodwind instruments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching techniques for clarinet and oboe
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to individual students

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. Designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching flute, bassoon, and saxophone (offered spring semesters).

Required of all instrumental music education students. Designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching the violin and viola and to explore instructional materials used with these instruments.  (offered fall semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying instructional materials for violin and viola
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adjusting teaching methods based on student progress
Analyzing student performance on violin and viola

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. The course is designed to develop basic skills of playing and teaching cello and string bass and to evaluate instructional materials used with these instruments.  Introduces heterogeneous teaching and rehearsal techniques using all four stringed instruments.  (offered spring semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluating instructional materials for stringed instruments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conducting rehearsals for all four stringed instruments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying effective instructional materials for stringed instruments
Implementing different teaching techniques based on individual student needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading rehearsals for all four stringed instruments
Organizing and planning lessons for cello and string bass

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. Class lessons on all percussion instruments and the study of teaching methods for these instruments.  (offered spring semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying teaching methods for percussion instruments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing feedback and guidance to students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to individual student needs
Identifying areas for improvement in student performance

courseTitle: Music Education: Music for the Elementary Classroom Teacher
courseDescription: Students gain skills and experience related to the use of music in elementary school.
Technical and Digital Skills: Music selection for various age groups
Integration of music technology in classroom
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating the importance of music education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting music lessons to different learning styles
Creating engaging and educational music activities

courseDescription: The development of basic skills and techniques necessary for conducting choral and instrumental ensembles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of instrumental and choral techniques

courseDescription: Required of all instrumental music education students. Class lessons on all percussion instruments and the study of teaching methods for these instruments. (offered fall semesters)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of teaching methods for individual students

courseDescription: This course is required of all music majors and music minors for six semesters of their enrollment as a music major or a music minor. The successful completion of the course requires attendance at a specified number of approved recitals, concerts, and events each semester.

This course covers the fundamentals of Digital Audio Workstations (DAWs) with a focus on Pro Tools. Students will learn basic editing techniques and gain proficiency in creating, arranging and comping tracks, workflow optimization through shortcuts, and basic mixing techniques Additionally, the course delves into the fundamentals of microphone choices and placement. This course emphasizes basic signal flow, the recording process, and troubleshooting skills necessary for a successful audio recording session.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of microphone choices and placement

courseDescription: This course focuses on the craft of songwriting.  Covering contemporary song forms, techniques of lyric and melody writing as well as popular harmony and analysis, the course prepares students to write hit songs.  Students will learn how to effectively demo their own songs, successfully collaborate, write jingles and copyright their own material.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative problem solving in song composition

courseDescription: Expanding on the digital audio workstation skills gained in MUSC 315, this course introduces the student to modern multitrack recording techniques. Topics include microphone choice and placement, recording studio signal flow, the use of a large-format console, precise and creative audio editing, file structure and organization, and the basics of signal processing. Students apply this knowledge through guided in-class activities and practical group studio sessions designed to enhance their problem-solving, communication, and critical listening skills. This course is for Bachelor of Music with Emphasis in Sound Recording Technology majors only.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving during in-class activities and practical group studio sessions

courseDescription: Music Theory 3 further develops skills learned previously in the theory sequence and introduces new topics including: writing and identifying diatonic sequences, spelling and resolving secondary dominants and leading-tone chords of V and scale degrees other than V, modulatory techniques (sequences, pivot chord, direct, common-tone), common-tone chords, NS chromatic modulations. Musical forms including binary, ternary, variation, Baroque forms, Sonata Form, etc. will be introduced and identification skills developed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Spelling and resolving secondary dominants and leading-tone chords of V and scale degrees other than V
Modulatory techniques including sequences, pivot chord, direct, common-tone
Understanding and applying common-tone chords and NS chromatic modulations
Identifying different musical forms such as binary, ternary, variation, Baroque forms, Sonata Form
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Sharing musical ideas and concepts with others
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting different musical forms
Resolving complex musical sequences and chords
Applying modulatory techniques to solve musical problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing individual music study
Leading group discussions on music theory topics

courseTitle: Advanced Music Theory and Post-Tonal Compositional Techniques
courseDescription: Topics explored in this course include: part-writing advanced chromatic harmonies and modulations, altered and extended chords, twentieth-century rhythmic techniques, pitch-class sets, analyzing with modes, scales, collections, and set theory, primitivism, basics of twelve-tone theory, and composing with twelve tones. Other topics explored include theoretical elements of composing after 1945, such as graphic and text notation, chance and indeterminacy, minimalism, post-modern music, and more recent trends.
Technical and Digital Skills: Part-writing advanced chromatic harmonies and modulations
Understanding and use of altered and extended chords
Understanding and analyzing with modes, scales, collections, and set theory
Understanding and application of twelve-tone theory
Understanding and application of graphic and text notation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting and explaining complex music theoretical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing music compositions with modes, scales, collections, and set theory
Interpreting and applying theoretical elements of composing after 1945
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing complex music compositions

courseDescription: A continuation of MUSC 224 and in close connection with topics covered in MUSC 321. Topics covered include chordal and chromatic harmony as well as written and keyboard work emphasizing skill development in harmonic modulation.

courseTitle: Advanced Aural Skills - Tonal and Beyond
courseDescription: A continuation of MUSC 323; recommended in conjunction with MUSC 322. Further development of skills learned in MUSC 323 with an additional focus on post-tonal techniques.

Musicians in the twenty-first century must be equipped to meet the ever-changing demands of the contemporary music industry through the development of an entrepreneurial mindset and the utilization of both musical and extra-musical skills, which will allow them to create and build sustainable careers. This course offers a foundation upon which students can develop the musical careers they seek and provides first-hand experience with some of the basic tools modern musicians need to succeed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of musical and extra-musical tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of musical ideas and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to changing demands in the music industry
Identifying opportunities for career growth and sustainability

courseDescription: This introductory course will explore the impact of technology on music performance, composition, and education through in-class lecture, hands-on demonstration, and lab projects. Topics covered include but are not limited to: basic acoustics, basic audio signal flow for live performance and recording, microphone basics for live performance and recording, an introduction to sequencing and recording software and Digital Audio Workstations, MIDI and synthesis, basics of mixing, editing, an introduction to music notation software and uses, creation of 'music minus one' projects for pedagogical purposes, and an exploration of common file formats for distribution and publication.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding audio signal flow for live performance and recording
Using microphones for live performance and recording
Introduction to sequencing and recording software
Understanding and using Digital Audio Workstations
Basics of mixing and editing music
Understanding common file formats for music distribution and publication
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creating and implementing 'music minus one' projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing different music projects
Leading a music performance or recording session

courseDescription: This introductory course is designed to give students a historical overview of mechanical and electronic music through topical study and listening examples.  Additionally, students will create their own electronic music compositions using analog, digital and virtual hardware/software.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of mechanical and electronic music history
Usage of analog and digital hardware
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of own electronic music composition
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary electronic music
Problem solving in music composition with hardware/software

courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the basic concepts of Jazz improvisation, including harmonic and melodic implications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of melodic implications in Jazz
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creating melodic responses to harmonic progressions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing musical ideas within an improvised framework

courseDescription: This course is a continuation of MUSC 337, and will delve further into more advanced techniques used in Jazz improvisation.

courseTitle: Synthesis and Sound Design Techniques for Music Production
courseDescription: An introduction to the fascinating world of sound synthesis and sound design through practical hands-on assignments using industry-standard techniques and by exploring the technology and historical evolution. The course will focus on subtractive synthesis; a core knowledge for creating one's own sounds to use in music.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical evolution of sound synthesis and sound design
Creating unique sounds for music production
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing sound design projects
Leading sound design process using subtractive synthesis

courseDescription: This course is designed for music and non-music majors interested in the fascinating world of film scoring. Through a combination of historical exploration and in-depth analysis of musical and narrative elements, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of how music enhances storytelling in the world of film and television.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of musical and narrative elements in film and television

courseDescription: An introductory course dealing with correct principles of effective diction essential to the singing of English and Italian songs.  (offered every fall)
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in singing English and Italian songs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and delivery of song lyrics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting singing techniques for different languages

courseDescription: An introductory course dealing with correct principles of effective diction essential to the singing of German and French songs.  (offered every spring)
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in singing German and French songs
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Verbal communication in German and French
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and correction of diction errors
Analysis of song lyrics for correct pronunciation

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the art of music notation through exploring the history of music engraving practices, hands-on experience writing music manuscript (hand-written) and the use of modern notation software (Finale, Sibelius, etc.) with MIDI implementation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of modern notation software like Finale and Sibelius
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting and applying historical music notation practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for hands-on music writing
Project management in music manuscript creation

courseDescription: Students develop critical listening skills through aural analysis, ear training, drill and practice, and comparative analyses. Topics covered include spectral balance and equalization, spatial attributes and reverberation, dynamic range control, distortion and noise, audio clip edit points, analysis of sound, frequencies, effects and processing, delays and decays, and master frequencies. Students are expected to identify frequency ranges, specific audio signatures, distortion, edits, and digit manipulation through aural examinations.

This course is designed to give students hands-on experience working with both hardware and software in the modern MIDI Production studio. Topics covered include MIDI recording, sequencing, editing, and playback techniques, virtual instruments and hardware synthesizers, tracking and mixing in a DAW, and file formats and distribution.
Technical and Digital Skills: Working with hardware in a MIDI Production studio
Working with virtual instruments and hardware synthesizers
Tracking and mixing in a DAW
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting hardware and software issues in a MIDI Production studio
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and organizing multiple file formats
Sequencing tasks in a MIDI Production process

courseTitle: History of Western Art Music from Ancient through Baroque
courseDescription: A survey of the development of western art music, from Ancient Greece through the Baroque, highlighting the influence of historical events upon musical developments.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical influences on musical development

courseTitle: History of Western Art Music from Classical through Modern
courseDescription: A survey of the development of western art music, from Classical through Modern, showing the influence of historical events upon musical development.  This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing a comprehensive research project

courseDescription: An opportunity to integrate service and applied learning experience with music industry perspectives.
This ensemble will explore Jazz literature, focusing primarily on the small group format.  Previous experience with improvisation is necessary for all participants.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to ensemble dynamics in real-time
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Lead or support roles within a Jazz ensemble

courseDescription: One to three rehearsal periods per week, depending on the ensemble.  Students will participate in rehearsals and public performances.
Studio class ensemble for strings. Meets once a week.
This is a performance-based course. It is designed to train music majors and non-majors in small ensemble choral techniques. This choral ensemble is an audition-only group.

Extracurricular activities may be approved for credit based on objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the student prior to the semester in which the activity is to take place.  Credit is subject to review by the provost.

Symphonic Band is a large ensemble for woodwind, brass and percussion players open to all university students with an audition for ensemble seating. Students will participate in rehearsals and concerts.
Participation in rehearsals and public performances of the Concert Choir.
Participation in rehearsals and public performances of the band.  Three rehearsal periods per week.
Participation in rehearsals and public performances of the University Symphony Orchestra.  Rehearsals two days per week and dress rehearsals TBA.
This instrumental group will explore and perform standard jazz literature for the Jazz Ensemble and the contemporary Jazz Orchestra.
Basketball band performs at all home Men's and Women's basketball games and selected tournament performances.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Quick adaptation to new music pieces

courseDescription: Vocal jazz ensemble, performing standard jazz choir literature.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management during rehearsals and performances

courseDescription: Small vocal ensemble focusing on a cappella classical music.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Error detection and correction in singing

courseDescription: Brass Ensemble consisting of trumpets, horns, trombones, euphoniums, and tubas.  Performing works written for brass as well as  arrangements of choral, orchestral, jazz, pop, and show music.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with diverse group of musicians
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret musical pieces
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a section of the ensemble

courseDescription: The Monarch Marching Band will meet only during the fall semester and perform at all home and some away football games and other selected events.  Students will participate in rehearsals and performances.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for rehearsals and performances

courseDescription: An ensemble comprised of a rhythm section and a few vocalists. Students will play musical covers and original songs in weekly rehearsals, and performs a live concert and/or records in the studio. Can be taken a maximum of 2 times for credit.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting to change in live performance

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule.  Course descriptions and prerequisites for each course may be found in information distributed to all academic advisors.

A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule.  Course descriptions and prerequisites for each course may be found in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Music
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Music
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Music Education: Elementary Vocal and General Methods
courseDescription: Required prior to student teaching for all students in music education.  Focuses on  materials and methods of vocal and general instruction for elementary music classrooms. (offered fall semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of vocal and general music instruction materials
Utilization of digital tools for music education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively teaching music to elementary students
Communicating complex musical concepts in an understandable manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting music teaching methods to diverse student needs
Evaluating the effectiveness of different music teaching materials

courseTitle: Music Education: Practicum (Elementary Vocal and General)
courseDescription: Required prior to the Teacher Candidate Internship (student teaching) for all students in music education. Enables students to observe master classroom teachers and to test accumulated teaching practices in elementary school vocal and general classroom settings. 20 hours of music classroom observation required. Also, in order to receive the required school practicum placement, students must have completed the ODU Office of Clinical Experiences background check/clearance process prior to the beginning of this course. The clearance process takes eight weeks. Students must register for the practicum placement on the Office of Clinical Experiences web pages prior to the course drop/add deadline. Students should contact their advisor for more information. (offered fall and spring semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with standard background check procedures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Classroom interaction with elementary school students
Collaboration with the Office of Clinical Experiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of teaching strategies in real-world situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in elementary school vocal and general classroom settings

courseDescription: Required prior to the Teacher Candidate Internship (student teaching) for all students in music education with voice, keyboard or guitar concentration. Focuses on methods of vocal instruction, materials and rehearsal methods for secondary vocal classroom settings. (offered spring semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of voice, keyboard or guitar concentration
Knowledge of rehearsal methods for secondary vocal classroom settings
Familiarity with materials relevant to secondary vocal music education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to convey musical concepts to students
Adaptability to different learning styles and abilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of teaching methods based on individual student needs
Ability to assess and improve vocal techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Classroom management in a musical setting

courseDescription: Required prior to student teaching for all students in music education with voice, keyboard or guitar concentration. Enables students to observe master teachers and to test accumulated teaching practices in secondary school vocal classroom settings. 20 hours of observation required. Passing score of 160 on the Praxis Subject assessment, music content knowledge examination (formerly Praxis II) and passing scores on the VCLA are requirements of this course.  Also, in order to receive the required school practicum placement, students must have completed the ODU Office of Clinical Experiences background check/clearance process prior to the beginning of this course. The clearance process takes eight weeks. Students must register for the practicum placement on the Office of Clinical Experiences web pages prior to the course drop/add deadline. Students should contact their advisor for more information. (offered fall and spring semesters).
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of teaching practices for secondary school vocal settings
Understanding of Praxis Subject assessment and VCLA requirements
Ability to navigate and register on the Office of Clinical Experiences web pages
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to observe and learn from master teachers
Communication with secondary school students in a vocal classroom setting
Interacting with advisor for course-related information
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to adapt teaching practices based on observed methods
Analyzing and understanding music content knowledge examination
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and completing the ODU Office of Clinical Experiences background check/clearance process
Organizing time to complete 20 hours of observation
Leadership in a secondary school vocal classroom setting

courseDescription: Required prior to the Teacher Candidate Internship (student teaching) for all students in music education with an instrumental music concentration.  Focuses on methods of instruction, materials and rehearsal methods for secondary instrumental classrooms. (offered spring semesters)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of instrumental music instruction methods
Knowledge of relevant materials for music education
Familiarity with rehearsal methods for secondary instrumental classrooms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate effective instructional methods
Interpersonal skills for managing student relationships
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to adapt instruction methods to different classroom needs
Problem-solving skills in handling rehearsals and teaching situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills in preparing materials and plans for music education

courseDescription: Required prior to the Teacher Candidate Internship (student teaching) for all students in music education with instrumental music concentration. Enables students to observe master teachers and to test accumulated teaching practices in secondary school instrumental classrooms. Passing score of 160 on the Praxis Subject assessment, music content knowledge examination (formerly Praxis II) and passing scores on the VCLA are requirements of this course. Also, in order to receive the required school practicum placement, students must have completed the ODU Office of Clinical Experiences background check/clearance process prior to the beginning of this course. The clearance process takes eight weeks. Students must register for the practicum placement on the Office of Clinical Experiences web pages prior to the course drop/add deadline. Students should contact their advisor for more information. Offered fall and spring semesters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of ODU Office of Clinical Experiences background check/clearance process
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a classroom setting
Building rapport with secondary school students

courseDescription: Required prior to the Teacher Candidate Internship (student teaching) for all students in music education with the vocal, keyboard and guitar concentration. Focuses on development of vocal majors' ability to read instrumental scores; provides vocal majors an understanding of families of instruments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of different families of instruments

courseDescription: This course is designed to assist students in enhancing their understanding of the aesthetic response to music in various settings.  Students will learn to integrate their understanding of musical aptitude as it relates to human growth and development.  In addition, students will study the psychological implication of personality types as they develop, implement, and assess their pedagogical approach.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of music in different settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting the impact of music in human growth and development
Implementing pedagogical methodology in relation to music
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessing pedagogical approach in relation to music
Analyzing the psychological implications of personality types in relation to music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing pedagogical approach based on psychological insights
Integrating musical understanding within educational settings

courseDescription: Course deals with the analysis, interpretation, and conducting of varied choral literature.
Course deals with the analysis, interpretation, and conducting of varied instrumental literature.

courseTitle: The Art and Craft of Mixing
courseDescription: In this course, students learn how to mix music that supports the emotion of the song and engages listeners. Topics include effective session preparation, advanced editing techniques, musical balancing, creative use of audio effects, and automation techniques. Students will work with pre-recorded multitracks, completing numerous mixes using plug-ins and outboard signal processors, and will receive in-depth critical feedback from their instructor and peers. Through this process, students will develop the critical listening and technical skills to confidently creatively shape sound. This course is for Bachelor of Music with Emphasis in Sound Recording Technology majors only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using plug-ins and outboard signal processors

courseTitle: Arranging for the Contemporary Musician and Producer
courseDescription: Students learn how to arrange music for rhythm sections, vocals, and diverse ensembles, including brass, woodwinds and strings. This course uniquely addresses the evolving landscape of modern music production, bridging the gap between virtual instruments and recording musicians in the studio. As the recording process evolves, so do the demands on musical arrangement and orchestration. This course provides students with the essential tools and techniques to adapt their arrangements to meet the needs of contemporary recording processes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with musicians in a studio setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting arrangements to meet recording needs
Analyzing the requirements of different musical sections
Creating solutions for evolving recording processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing music arrangements for multiple instrument types

courseDescription: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of record production, focusing on creative and technical aspects. Topics include pre-production, song arrangement choices, collaboration with artists, and advanced mixing skills. The final project involves planning, producing, and presenting a complete music production project, with peer feedback and analysis. Students in this course will develop essential skills for successful music careers, emphasizing creativity and technical proficiency.
A study of the contrapuntal techniques of sixteenth century composers and their influence upon composers of the eighteenth through twentieth centuries.  (offered fall, even years)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Sixteenth Century Contrapuntal Techniques
Knowledge of Eighteenth to Twentieth Century Composers' Techniques

courseDescription: Aural analysis study and analysis of the principal traditional musical forms.  Stylistic and harmonic analysis as it related to score study will be discussed.  (offered spring, even years)

A study of the range, musical functions, and technical characteristics of the instruments and their color possibilities in various combinations. Practical experience in scoring for small and large ensembles.  (offered fall, odd years)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of technical characteristics of instruments
Practical scoring for small and large ensembles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing instrument color possibilities in various combinations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing different instruments in an ensemble

courseDescription: Students will learn how to chart and arrange music for the marching band.  In addition, basic vocal arranging techniques will be discussed.  Students will be required to observe different styles of school marching bands.
Technical and Digital Skills: Observation and analysis of different marching band styles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adaptability to different styles and techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in directing and coordinating band performances

courseDescription: This course builds upon the fundamentals experienced in the introductory MIDI course.  Topics include: advanced sequencing techniques, looping, editing, data manipulation, patch and control changes through real-time recording, patch editing, storage and retrieval, incorporation of external hardware, sampling, and an introduction to the incorporation of digital audio.
Technical and Digital Skills: Patch and control changes through real-time recording
Introduction to the incorporation of digital audio

courseDescription: This is a hands-on course in the art of film composition. Students will analyze iconic film scores from Bernard Herrmann to John Powell, exploring music's narrative impact, gain insight into the modern composer’s workflow and diverse skill sets, and apply the techniques learned in practical projects, transitioning from sketch to demo using a DAW. The course culminates in a recording session for the final project. This projects allows students to practice film spotting, thematic writing, sketch to demo production, arranging and music preparation for a live recording experience. Students elevate their skills in writing music that uniquely supports and enhances visual storytelling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying a modern composer’s workflow
Transitioning from sketch to demo using a DAW
Music preparation for a live recording experience
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpreting the narrative requirements for music composition
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and evaluation of film scores
Applying techniques learned in practical projects
Evaluating and enhancing music that supports visual storytelling
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and executing a final project

courseDescription: Teaching techniques, literature in the performing area.  Seminar deals with resource materials.  Laboratory:  observation and teaching under supervision.
Technical and Digital Skills: Literature analysis in the performing area

courseDescription: Teaching techniques, literature in the performing area.  Seminar portion of the course deals with resource materials.  Laboratory portion of the course includes observation and teaching under supervision.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods based on observation

courseDescription: This course will study the historical development of jazz as an American art form.  The emotion and meaning of this style will be investigated as well as the historical and contemporary aesthetic response.  Emphasis will include the defining role of African American artists.  The influence of jazz on the development of contemporary American music will be discussed.  Written critiques of live performances will be required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulating historical and contemporary aesthetic responses

courseDescription: The course covers how music has co-evolved with technology, the entertainment business, and cultural trends. The main theme is how recording technology has evolved, and with it, the music making and music listening experiences. Students will expand their musical vocabulary through the study of numerous musical genres, listening to and discussing the essential elements of impactful records, and learning about key artists, composers, producers, engineers, and other music professionals (both past and present). Students will gain a better understanding of the role music plays in the entertainment industry, including with film, TV, games, social media, live events, and more.
Technical and Digital Skills: Insights into the role of music in different entertainment platforms
Awareness of the music making and music listening experiences
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of essential elements of impactful records
Appreciation and knowledge sharing about key artists, composers, producers, engineers, and other music professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of the co-evolution of music and technology
Understanding the impact of cultural trends on music

courseDescription: Hip-hop, from local roots to global dominance, has sparked extensive journalistic and academic exploration primarily focused on its social and cultural impacts. This course delves into the historical factors shaping hip-hop's origin and evolution, examines its global success and translation both musically and linguistically, and engages in contemplation regarding the essence and direction of hip-hop. No prior musical experience or knowledge of music notation is required, but students will develop a basic set of skills for discussing the structure and function of hip-hop songs.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and analysis of hip-hop songs
Exploration of social and cultural impacts of hip-hop
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical factors shaping hip-hop
Critical contemplation on the essence and direction of hip-hop

courseTitle: Music of the 20th Century to the Present
courseDescription: A study of the techniques and styles in music in the twentieth and twenty-first century (offered spring).
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and articulate understanding of music techniques and styles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of music structures and styles

courseTitle: Music History from the Ancient to Baroque Era
courseDescription: Study of music history (specific topics vary) including historical perspective in relation to style and development of music, and the function of music in society and culture.  Topics will be from the Ancient through the Baroque era (offered fall semester).
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of different musical styles and their development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical context of musical pieces
Critical thinking and interpretation of music history

courseTitle: Music History from the Classical through Modern Era
courseDescription: Study of music history (specific topics vary) including historical perspective in relation to style and development of music, and the function of music in society and culture.  Topics will be from the Classical through Modern era.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and interpretation of music pieces
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of music's role within society and culture

courseDescription: A study of music history from the late works of Beethoven to Mahler and Strauss.  A discussion of musical style within the context of cultural history. (spring semesters, even years)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of Beethoven, Mahler, and Strauss' works
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing musical style within historical context
Comparative analysis of different composers' works

courseDescription: These courses will appear in the course schedule.  Course descriptions and prerequisites for each course may be found in information distributed to all academic advisors.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Music
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Topics in Music
courseDescription: Independent reading and study on a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor.  Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in music theory or history
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Meeting deadlines for papers and conferences

courseDescription: This course is designed to assist students in enhancing their understanding of the aesthetic response to music in various settings.  Students will learn to integrate their understanding of musical aptitude as it relates to human growth and development.  In addition, students will study the psychological implication of personality types as they develop, implement, and assess their pedagogical approach.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of human growth and development patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing different personality types in various settings

courseDescription: Aural analysis study and analysis of the principal traditional musical forms.  Stylistic and harmonic analysis as it related to score study will be discussed.

Students will learn how to chart and arrange music for the marching band. In addition, basic vocal arranging techniques will be discussed. Students will be required to observe different styles of school marching bands.
Technical and Digital Skills: Recognizing and differentiating marching band styles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Observation and analysis of different school marching band styles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting music arrangements to fit band style
Problem solving in arranging complex music charts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing music pieces for band performance

The course culminates in a recording session for the final project. This projects allows students to practice film spotting, thematic writing, sketch to demo production, arranging and music preparation for a live recording experience. Students elevate their skills in writing music that uniquely supports and enhances visual storytelling.

courseDescription: Teaching techniques, literature in the performing area.  Seminar deals with resource materials.  Laboratory:  observation and teaching under supervision.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of literature in the performing areas
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating complex information about music performance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching techniques to individual students
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and instructing during laboratory sessions

courseDescription: This course will study the historical development of jazz as an American art form.  The emotion and meaning of this style will be investigated as well as the historical and contemporary aesthetic response.  Emphasis will include the defining role of African American artists.  The influence of jazz on the development of contemporary American music will be discussed. A research paper will be required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary aesthetic responses
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and conveying complex historical and artistic concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of music and art
Analysis of cultural influence and impact

courseDescription: The course covers how music has co-evolved with technology, the entertainment business, and cultural trends. The main theme is how recording technology has evolved, and with it, the music making and music listening experiences. Students will expand their musical vocabulary through the study of numerous musical genres, listening to and discussing the essential elements of impactful records, and learning about key artists, composers, producers, engineers, and other music professionals (both past and present). Students will gain a better understanding of the role music plays in the entertainment industry, including with film, TV, games, social media, live events, and more.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of music's role in various entertainment mediums
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing and analyzing essential elements of impactful records
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing cultural trends and their impact on music

courseDescription: Hip-hop, from local roots to global dominance, has sparked extensive journalistic and academic exploration primarily focused on its social and cultural impacts. This course delves into the historical factors shaping hip-hop's origin and evolution, examines its global success and translation both musically and linguistically, and engages in contemplation regarding the essence and direction of hip-hop. No prior musical experience or knowledge of music notation is required, but students will develop a basic set of skills for discussing the structure and function of hip-hop songs.

courseDescription: This course is designed to assist music students to enhance their understanding of musicians' health issues in order to prepare them to achieve their desired performance potential.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of health issues to other musicians
Empathy for health-related challenges faced by musicians
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and mitigation of health issues affecting musical performance
Analysis of performance potential and underlying health factors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-management of health for consistent performance
Advocacy for musicians' health within a musical ensemble or organization

courseTitle: Music History from the Ancient to Baroque Era
courseDescription: Study of music history (specific topics vary) including historical perspective in relation to style and development of music, and the function of music in society and culture.  Topics will be from the Ancient through the Baroque era (offered fall semester).
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of music development from Ancient to Baroque Era
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion about the role of music in society and culture
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of musical style evolution
Understanding of the societal and cultural influences on music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on music history topics

courseTitle: Music History from the Classical through Modern Era
courseDescription: Study of music history (specific topics vary) including historical perspective in relation to style and development of music, and the function of music in society and culture.  Topics will be from the Classical through Modern era.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying musical style and development trends
Understanding the role of music in various cultural contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debating different perspectives on music development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting the societal impact of music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on music history

courseDescription: A study of music history from the late works of Beethoven to Mahler and Strauss.  A discussion of musical style within the context of cultural history. (offered spring, even years)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of musical styles of the Romantic period
Knowledge of works by Beethoven, Mahler, and Strauss
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of musical styles within cultural history context

courseDescription: This course should be taken among the first courses in the Master of Music Education program.  Introduces graduate students to basic skills in Music Education research, including bibliographic searches, on-line searches, computer data analysis, and conventions of scholarly writing for reporting findings.

Examines techniques and concepts applied to compositions of the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries as well as modern music, through analysis of contrapuntal and harmonic textures, form, and performance practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of contrapuntal and harmonic textures
Understanding of eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries compositions

courseDescription: Methods, techniques, principles, and tools of music education, with reference to various types of school situations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of various music education methods
Proficiency in using music education tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to adapt teaching methods to different school situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of music education techniques
Solving problems related to music education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing music education sessions

courseDescription: This course involves the study of the philosophical, psychological and historical foundations of music related to curriculum development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in philosophical and psychological aspects of music
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss and explain historical and philosophical contexts of music
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and psychological effects on music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and integrating historical, philosophical, and psychological elements into curriculum

courseDescription: The course centers upon the study of the performance, review and analysis of music for the Symphonic Band and Wind Ensemble.  Suited especially to the needs of directors of secondary school and other nonprofessional wind ensembles.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the structure and style of wind ensemble music
Developing strategies for improving ensemble performance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and managing nonprofessional wind ensembles

courseDescription: Survey of choral literature and practical performance practices from the Renaissance to the present.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to identify different periods of choral music from Renaissance to present
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to perform choral music in a group

courseDescription: This course is a study of basic Orff Schulwerk techniques.  Level I pedagogy includes instruction in the use of pentatonic scale, ostinato, elemental forms, improvisation, basic body movement and basic soprano recorder skills.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of elemental forms

courseDescription: This course is a survey of standard repertoire written for string and symphony orchestra, including score analysis and study of historical context and performance practice. Selected educational repertoire will also be explored in relation to similar counterparts in the standard repertoire. Suited for music educators and developing conductors.
This course will build upon the skills and concepts introduced in Orff Schulwerk Levels I and II.  Recorder technique will be expanded upon as well as eurhythmics and special topics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and Applying Orff Schulwerk Concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching and Communicating Orff Schulwerk Concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative Problem Solving in Musical Contexts

courseTitle: Current Trends in Elementary and Secondary Music
courseDescription: Designed for public school music teachers.  This course involves the study of current methodology, its practice and uses in the elementary and secondary general/vocal/instrumental music program.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge about general/vocal/instrumental music programs in schools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain and demonstrate musical techniques
Ability to communicate music program objectives and methodologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to suit different music programs

courseTitle: Organization and Administration of Instrumental Music
courseDescription: The course involves the study of effective organization and implementation techniques for elementary and secondary instrumental ensembles; includes particular problems in the administration of high school instrumental groups.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing particular problems in high school instrumental groups
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing elementary and secondary instrumental ensembles
Leading and managing high school instrumental groups

courseDescription: This course centers upon the development of performance and instructional skills in various aspects of music education.  May be repeated twice with different emphases.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding various aspects of music education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to various aspects of music education

courseDescription: The course centers upon the development of performance and instrumental skills in various aspects of instrumental music.  May be repeated twice with different emphases.
This course centers upon the development of conducting techniques, performance and instructional skills in various aspects of choral music.  May be repeated twice with different emphases.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building rapport within a choral group
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting conducting techniques to specific choral music
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in conducting a choral group

courseDescription: Involves conducting techniques as applied to various mixed ensembles.  Emphasizes the technical considerations common to all phases of choral and instrumental conducting with special concern for school problems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with different ensemble members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting conducting techniques to different mixed ensembles

courseDescription: Types of research, selection of problems, location of educational information, collection and classification of data, organization, presentation and interpretation of materials in the area of music education.

This course supports music educators in their goal of producing engaging educational experiences for their students. Topics include essential audio skills, basic video production, the entertainment business, music composition for various contexts, music apps, and more. Students learn through practical projects, receiving detailed feedback on their work. The technological tools would be put within the context of culture, current musical and business trends, and creative pedagogy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and applying current musical and business trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying technological tools within cultural contexts

courseTitle: Techniques of Jazz Education in the Secondary School
courseDescription: This course will deal with rehearsal techniques for the Jazz Ensemble, including articulation, style, phrasing, literature, and improvisational techniques.  In addition, Jazz history and literature will be discussed in detail.
Technical and Digital Skills: Rehearsal techniques for the Jazz Ensemble

courseDescription: Students are expected to help with sectional rehearsals and do in-depth score study on all music being performed.

This course is designed to guide the student who is completing the Pedagogical Concentration in developing a professional teaching portfolio. It would typically be taken during the last semester of the degree program. The portfolio will be completed in digital format suitable for professional use. It will include information in the following areas: professional foundations, scholarship, performance, applied pedagogy and other professional data pertinent to the focus of the student.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading professional development via portfolio creation

courseDescription: These courses will appear in the course schedule. Course descriptions and prerequisites for each course may be found in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Designed for individualized study.  Independent study projects will be related to music education and done under the supervision of a certified faculty member.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of musical knowledge and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptive learning and problem solving in music education

courseDescription: Application of research procedures in music education, culminating in student study of selected topics.

courseTitle: Thesis for Master of Music Education
courseDescription: Completion of thesis for the Master of Music Education degree.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of music education literature

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
